content:
r 23, 2014
												For claification sake, I've played this game since Beta and I love the overall animation and playstyle imaged as a 2D platformer. I guess this really hit a nostalgia nerve for me and my yearning for the old Mario Brothers mechanics. And while I hate to bash something I fell in love with, this is no longer the game that I use to know.Back in the early days of MapleStory, you had your 4 standard classes: Mage, Warrior, Archer, Thief. Mage and Warrior had 3 subsets each; Archer and Thief had 2 subsets. Finding equipment and hanging out with friends was easy because there was just a few servers and not that many maps. The level cap was set as a crazy 200, but the mindless grinding wasn't so bad, cause you could easily be with your friends and if you found an equip you couldn't use, one of them could and vice versa.But Maplestory grew. On the surface, you would think this is a good thing; more people = more friends = more equips. True, but Nexon saw this as an excellent opportunity to milk its players through microtransactions. As the game grew, Nexon built more servers and maps, creating virtual spacial rifts between players. It became more and more difficult to get to the same map as a friend without using a teleport rock (a microtransaction item) or wasting a bunch of time. Nexon created pets, vanity items, world transfers, shops; all for real money. When that wasn't enough, they created more character types, those who couldn't share the cash shop items with the original characters, essentially urging players to rebuy cash items. The new characters also lead to the nerfing of some of the original characters under the guise of "improved" for rebalancing issues. Nexon raised the level cap to 250, milking players for even longer. They created a lottery system called gachapon for in-game items using real money, not to mention special event "lotteries".Don't play Maplestory. It's not what it use to be. The fun is sucked out of it. Don't waste tons of time and money on it like I did.

number of helpful: 542 of 647 people (84%) found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												MapleStory was one of the first MMORPG titles I've had the chance of playing, besides Runescape Classic (which was a looong time ago).After a revisit of this game (after many years of on and off playing), as well as THOUSANDS of dollars spent, I cannot say I am willing to recommend this game.FIrstly, MapleStory is one of the few 2D side-scrolling MMORPGs that try to mix 'cute' and 'breathtaking' together, and at times, they do it very well. Some landscapes are huge, the original lore and locations were very well done, and one can be trapped in the game's beauty for long periods of time. Heck, even getting lost in that game was fun. However, with the changes as of the last two to three years, a lot of the beauty has been lost. In order to cater to the broader generation of players who demand instant gratification, they have changed out most of the old expansive locations and replaced them with compacted versions - so that players can traverse the world much more quickly. However, by doing so, they've stuffed all the game's content into the newer maps, which makes most of the world appear small and claustrophobic.The music score for this game is wonderful. Whether you're inside the forests of Ellinia, or exploring the depths of Ludibrium,  the background music really amplifies the mystery and beauty the game world is trying to become.The original MapleStory had a handful of classes, and each of them were unique, but overall balanced. Now, each large 'class update' seems to focus on newer 'Hero' characters, most who severely outclass the older counterparts in terms of damage and flashiness. In fact, there are so many different 'Heroes' nowadays, it saddens me to say that you'll rarely run into the older classes anymore, except in the case of Legacy worlds. The Cash Shop isn't all too great either. In addition to the standard cosmetic items and EXP boosts that one would commonly find in Free-2-Play MMOs, there are also items which give you in game currency, some which would offer you lowered failure chances when upgrading items. The latter gives players who spend a huge lead over players who don't, and this is made obvious by the overly high prices those items fetch on the marketplace.Combine that with a marketplace that doesn't let players open one without forking cash (and depending on how much cash you're willing to spend, it also determines whether you'll have to stay logged in to sell items)(players are only able to trade, so they'll have to solicit people in the market entrances) and a bad support team, I truly cannot recommend this game to anyone. MapleStory's golden days are long gone, and what's left is a carcass of what was once a masterpiece.

0, 2015
												I've played this game since I was 10 years old when it came out in america.The best way to describe maplestory is a deep, deep hole out in the woods.When you are bored and looking for something to do you fall into this hole.At first you are scared, you panic and try to get out of the hole.But slowly, you begin you like it in the hole. You spend thousands of dollars on making this hole cooler, nicer, and do more dps. You meet friends, lovers, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥s inside of this hole, it begins to feel like a community.Then high school girl drama will go down, and you will sell all your gear and quit.You will struggle to climb out of this hole. And finally....you're out.You go back to the way your life was before, and you become happy again.After a couple of months...you feel this craving...this...hunger...You miss the hole. Sure, the hole has its ups and downs...but you...you were safe in the hole...you were...home...So you go back, and thus begins the never ending downward spiral of your life.10/10 would quit and play again.

content:
er 12, 2014
Review as follows: Simple version up top, detailed on "read more". Note: I have played this game for well over 2,000+ hours over the years, and long before it was released on steam; how I ever racked up that many hours I will never know, but the game is not worth even 1 hour of your playtime.The good:  A classic 2D action platformer  Many character classes  Many areas to explore  The Bad  Character classes are horribly balanced  Classes do not particularly stand out from each other  (their niche's all blur together now) There is a huge problem with botters and hackers (people using cheats)  Traveling is a serious pain, and they draw it out ALOT to make you want to spend $$ money to make it easier.  Items purchased with $$ have a time limit (usually 90 days) The Worst   The game is so horribly coded it takes approx 2+ minutes to start even on high end computers  it will often take several attempts to start the game in order to start up properly (you will be getting lots of errors) The game crashes FREQUENTLY you could be playing for 5 minutes and it will crash so hard you must force shut down your computer  The game servers frequently need extended maintanence (often emergency maintenece; occurs several times a week)They force you to pay $$ real cash to have or upgrade abilities your character should have to begin with (such as the ability to hit criticals with magic attacks; which is INVALUABLE)  They make quests and grinding require so much travel you are essentially forced to purchase teleport rocks or other timesavers  Dying is exceptionally easy at higher levels, even the best gear can get you killed in as little as 5 hits (which you can get hit about every second), if you want to avoid the 10% exp loss you have to buy consumable "charms" to negate the 10% exp loss (which is many hours of work at higher levels).  Looting is atrocious (essentially requires spending $$ to get pets and items to have them loot for you.  They create artifical demandOn to the detailed and truely abominable things that make this game horrendous, almost beyond words. Fundamentally flawedThe simple act of looting is to push the "loot" button which is both "Z" and the numpad 0. As you progress through the game the method for fighting "mobs" is at the bucket loads, you will be killing 4~12 monsters within every 5 seconds. Each monster drops 2~4 items which are money, a misc monster drop, a potion, and a "ticket fragment" of sorts to do a special instance run that is always dead (no one does them.). So for every item you want to pickup, you must push "Z" and you will find that you will quickly be pushing that key hundreds if not THOUSANDS of times every few minutes. And if you dont loot those items you make essentially no money. The entire economy is seriously inflated to begin with too. If you want looting to be convenient be prepared to shell out about $30~$40 every 90 days for a pet and its "gear" to make it run around to loot things for you.You are forced to struggle with inventory space. At first you may think that you have plenty of space, but you quickly find out that the "Use" items and "misc" tabs will quickly be overlowing from NECESSARY items (the several hundred or THOUSAND potions you will be carrying, and have to replace every few hours or so). while the ETC slot will be filled with quest items, materials for crafting, and of course the hoards of monster drops you will be picking up (which usually only stack up to 200).Items you buy with $$ are NOT account-wide. They use a nonsense "cash inventory" system which is only shared with other characters of the same class (except in some rare caes like the "adventurer" series of classes or the "cygnus knights." However after the addition of the resistance they have their own shared cash inventory as well. You may think that is good enough but it IS NOT! because there are 2x of all that combined in classes that have a cash inventory shared only with other characters of the same class (which is POINTLESS because then you would be leveling up the exact same thing all over again; as each class only has 1 build, a special exception is made few 2 or 3 classes which can be either 1 element or another). Please note I am not talking about how a magician splits off into ice/lightning or fire/poison, I am referring to how a single class with a single skillset can have skills you wont want to invest in because they have no real part in the only effective way to create your character; which can be ever so important as there are skills in future advancements that require some certain skills to be Maxed.).They purposefully make things that should be everyday and easy access functions, exceedingly hard. For example, if you want to sell ANYTHING to ANY players, you want to go to the "free market" with about 50 other people, all spamming trying to sell things. If you want to sell ANYTHING as easily as it should be, you have to spend about ~$5 to buy a shop that your character has to man (lasts 90 days) just to sell things, which is horrendous in itself because you cant play the game, and it has a tendency to CRASH FREQUENTLY, and so hard you will have to FORCE SHUTDOWN YOUR PC!. So if you want to sell things as effectively as it should be, you have to spend $10 USD+ just to setup a store that will sell things for you (you set prices), and those can last 1 day to 7 days (getting more expensive for longer, up to $30 USD.) Character balancing is pitiful They come out with new character classes OFTEN! I swear, whenever you start getting your character to a high enough level to be happy with it, they release something that will outclass you in EVERY WAY! and you will essentially be forced to play that newest class since the monsters only get stronger to keep competing with the newest classes. And dont expect your old class to get revamped any time soon! it took them well over 3 years just to update the adventurers ONCE. and over a year for most anything else. In some cases the skillsets even change so completely you wont even recognize what to put your skill points into! but it gets WORSE! because if you make a mistake you will have to spend the $5+ USD to reset your points and hope you get it right the next time. It used to be that you had to spend about that much to reset a SINGLE POINT! and most skills require 20 or 30, im sure you can see how atrocious that is (the complete reset is only a new addition too, if you wanted reset you had to wait until they revamp your class again, because customer service WILL NOT HELP YOU!Customer service from Nexon is essentially non-existant, in fact, 99% of any and all messages you will get from them are automated. And no matter how large or small your problem is, nothing will be done. Your account getting hacked, or a broken quest (some havent been fixed for 2+ years), maybe even missing items/progress from a rollback, you will not get any help.There is no acceptable passive regen's (% or fixed numbers) for being in or out of combat, the only class that had one (the Jett) was removed with their revamp. So of course you must rely on potions ENTIRELY for you healing (unless you are a healer of sorts). The only passive regen you do have is 10hp for standing still for 10 seconds, and at higher levels (something you quickly reach) you have 7,000+ HP easy. while mana regen's at 3, which your mana is easily over 2,000 regardless of class (mages can go up to 30,000).There are countless more horrible things I can tell you about, but i feel I have made my point, and I beleive this is enough reasons why this game is among the things you should never play. Comments and likes are greatly appreciated! lets get the word out on why this is an awful game!

content:
, 2014
												I have no idea if Steam will say at all if I've played Maplestory but I promise you all I have put a lot of time into this game and absolutely loved every minute. Unfortunately Maplestory just became completely uninteresting since I've tried to relive it. And it makes me really sad. Maplestory originally had the classes we all see in every MMO (no matter how hard other MMO's try to make it different) and of course also like every MMO it started off simple. One big difference of course was the fact that it was a 2D sidescrolling MMOPRG and it's done so beautifully. You can make different faces at people depending on how you feel which was really fun before the cliche "lol" and "lmao" texts we all now universally know. Getting weapons was also a little more unique since most MMO's just milk weapons. Now a lot of MMORPG's have bows with unlimited arrows and guns with unlimited bullets. Maplestory made you buy arrows and throwing stars/shuriken if you wanted to be a ranged class. And Mesos (Maplestory currency) was hard to come by at low levels making it even more challenging since you had to actually ask for money from time to time.When I originally loved this amazing piece of gaming art you had to use a taxi to get to different cities (which you still do at least) and use flying boats to get to different continents. This was a huge deal because it allowed you to just settle down for a short time and actually talk to people; and listen to music along the way. Now this is not the case. There were no overpowered and annoyingly voice acted 'Hero' classes that literally kill everything in their paths with ease. You really had to work to get more powerful back then and you also needed to manually know what your stats needed to be for your class. Maplestory added more powerful classes over time but they were never 'Hero' status. Yes they got more powerful due to their unique skills compared to the default classes; however you still needed to start off as a default class and work your way into the more unique class you selected and leveling was still just as hard for you as the rest. The music is still the same Maplestory anime music I know and love. I just wish it could be heard with the game I knew and loved. For all you new players out there reading this review it'll mean close to nothing probably. To shorten what I just said: Maplestory used to be a surprisingly vast game filled with lots of social opportunity and hours upon hours of questing and leveling. It's a shell of its former self now. This does not mean I say it's a bad game. It's still good and worth the try. But unfortunately you have missed the golden age that was Maplestory. It's all milked down and I can't recommend it in its state now. What used to take a couple weeks to a month takes less than a day now. Bosses that originally required a full team can easily be defeated solo and the monsters that were originally intimidating and powerful are powerless. The challenge is gone. I will miss you Maplestory.

content:
ry 28, 2015
												MapleStory is that one game you're probably never going to find another of its calibre. It has that feel of nostalgia, even if you're new to the game. Attractive art styles look cartoony and cute while retaining 2d and pixelation draw people in this game with its surprising uniqueness. Maplestory has been breathing since 2005, but is it stable breathing?-Leveling-Maplestory was in its prime long back when generation Y was around 6 years old (2005 debut). If you compare the leveling from old Maplestory to post-big bang Maplestory, youll notice a huge difference. Its easier to hit level 100 nowadays, but back then whoever was over level 100 was considered a god. Old Maplestory had challenging leveling, so challenging that it took months to hit just 50. If you see the game now, it's a joke to hit 50, a 5 year old could do it in an hour.Of course Maplestory's leveling system will never be as good as it was back then; it evolves for newer audience because Nexon know the older audience will eventually quit. This is an instant gradification era, people want to level up quickly, not like a snail, to a point where it bores them to level up only 10 times a week. So, Nexon implemented an easier leveling system. One could argue that Nexon actually saved the game from dying off earlier.I won't argue anymore about Nexon saving the game with the leveling system, I used to think it was a saving throw, but I realized it's pretty much easy if you have enough change in your pockets. You can buy your levels. That's right. Nexon milked the leveling system for money. (by buy I mean buying 2x coupons and smashing keys to hit 200 easy peasy granted you have the money)-You ultimately don't have to spend money, but it makes you look/feel like trash-Nexon milked this game so much that its clear instead of a thick white. You ultimately don't have to spend money, since you CAN get anything you need without money. Let me elobrate, of course its convenient to buy cubes instead of pressing your mouse to farm for minerals and craft one, so the obvious logic is to do illegal activites and buy nexon points with mesos, the ingame currency, from a shady dealer with -239 downvotes. This game isn't really Pay 2 Win, it's more of Pay 4 Convenience. P4C makes you look like japanese eyecandy to people who get turned on to pixels, and makes your equipment hit like train, if that train holds 5 billion damage per hit.But if you don't P4C, you look like absolute crap until you muster enough mesos to buy one permanent nx item that looks decent. Gaining mesos from scratch is a timewaster too, because to merch (the term for buying low, selling high) without staring at your screen and hitting up and down to cycle messages, you have to pay real money to get a stand that does it for you, for about a month. Then you gotta buy it again if you want to merch, or get Carpal Tunnel. Oh, also, unless you spend alot of time and logical thinking on cubing and boosting stats on CRA, might as well fight with a stick because you are doing absolutely nothing to bosses that matter.-The Community-It sucks. Everyone will screw you over. I've seen too many stories when people grow up and try something like CSGO and leave for a month and the guild they had a blood pact with kicks them out, no matter how much they've contributed real life money for. People rarely work together anymore with strangers, guilds are just IRL friend camaradies, or a bunch of snobs who have superiority issues. Nexon realized this, but made it worse because they've made the entire game soloable (of course with money.) The community is just like anti-social teenagers at that one lunch table, if those teenagers tell you to CC if you step into their precious room.-Conclusion-This game, stripped of everything but gameplay, is so great. I love Maplestory's gameplay. I love it. But Nexon made a semi-working money making machine off of it, and completely ruined it for the veterans. I still play it on and off like that one chick in middle school, but Nexon makes so many schemes for cash and I can't believe people are blindlessly falling for it. Don't be tempted to buy that 90 day hair. Either voice your opinion of change to Nexon, or leave the game. It's not worth your time.

content:
r 18, 2014
												I remember waking up as a kid, excited and eager to start up my dad's computer, hopping into the world of Maplestory, ready to take on whatever the game was going to throw at me that day. Needless to say, I was hooked. The cartoony yet oddly satisfying visuals, the huge world that was set before me, the deceptively simple class system, all things that I adored about it. For a while, I couldn't get enough of this game. It was my first MMO ever, and, to this day, probably still my favorite. Nothing comes close to the fun I had while killing mushrooms in the starting zone, slaying Balrogs on airships, destroying robots in Ludi, and finally, conquering Zakum. I made many friends, joined a slew of guilds, and mostly, just had fun. That's what videogames were about back when I played Maplestory, and in a sense, it seems like they've kind of lost that recently, although that's a different topic entirely. Maplestory now seems to be much more oversaturated in terms of classes and things to do, actually making it an overwhemingly experience rather than an extremely enjoyable one, one that I had when I played. Needless to say however, I still had a HUGE amount of fun with this game, and is hands-down one of the best experiences, if not THE best, I've had in gaming. I cannot speak to the community now, but when I was playing, it was a bunch of generous and fun loving people, one's that were willing to help others when they needed it. I miss Maplestory, specifically old Maplestory, even more specifically v.066, when things were simpler and I had a bunch of NX to spend on a different hairstyle. I miss you Maplestory. Thanks for giving me the game of a lifetime.

content:
, 2015
												Oh man has this game died so much. When I first began playing which was in 2009, the Maplestory community was the best gaming community I had EVER experienced. The social aspect of the game was absolutely amazing. Back then, Factions weren't dead and every day I would find interesting people to play with and party up with. Now, maps are relatively quiet and empty, and you never get the party invites and friendliness that there used to be. People just farm to themselves and the amount of people playing has dropped  so much  that I feel like I'm playing on empty servers all of the time. People don't even bother talk to you and in the major cities all you find is afk players just sitting there waiting for you to rank up their fame. Gameplay has also changed for the worse too. Back then there were relatively few and DISTINCTIVE classes that were unique and gave the game a balanced and helpful feel. Nowadays there is just a bunch of classes that are very similar and their niches are intertwined so much that you feel like class choice doesn't really give you a new and fun experience anymore. They've also emphasized microtransactions too much that it just takes away from the game. Overall, you feel like you're playing in a largely empty singleplayer game that's not even fun because the social aspect has completely rotted to nonexistence and the large amounts of "events" that fail at trying to make the game more interesting. The game has died and I must admit that even if you pay lots of money to level up and look cool, it doesn't matter a single ounce in the end because you've wasted your hard earned captical on a game with a meaningless and dead world and community.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												A once-great game with a rather unique style, ruined by balance changes homogenizing all the classes, pay-to-win power creep, and no customer support.Aside from the graphics of skills being different and some classes requiring ammunition to use theirs, it's all a matter of using the fastest skill that hits multiple times so you can hit the damage cap twelve times in a single attack. With the occasional buff to prevent the bosses from instagibbing you with one of their attacks.The only challenge most bosses in this game have come from one of two factors: 1, Attacks that reduce your health and mana to 1, dispel your buffs, or take control away from your character.2. Having HP totals somewhere in the billions, and a short time limit to bring that to zero. Not a problem for people who hit the damage cap with every attack (50,000,000), but for people too self-aware to spend loads of dosh on cash items to upgrade in-game equipment they're impossible.Getting away from the game mechanics, the servers are infested with hackers and botters. How infested? There are more botters in the game than actual players. There's a "Report to GM" function, but if a GM actually responds to it, you should probably either buy a lottery ticket, or more likely slap yourself in the face because you are in a dream world where the impossible is possible. GMs only show up to host godawful events and spam emoticons while spouting lies.On that note, the game has an autoban function built into it, which 90% of the time bans nonhackers doing something mundane for no reason. On the off chance a hacker/botter actually is banned, they'll eventually be unbanned because Nexon likes giving people "second chances" and unbanning everyone who was ever banned up to that point. Why? Because hackers spend money too ya know! Gotta keep profits up!I said there is no customer support, but I was lying. There is a customer support ticket system, but it would probably better if it didn't exist at all. Tickets can go without a response for literally years. Nexon also has this opinion that having your account hacked into is the player's fault and refuses to compensate. One of the Global exclusive areas even has a quest line that mocks this, giving the middle finger to everyone who had their account broken into and laughing at them.Long story short, Unique art-style Platformer-MMORPG that crashed and burned and then was grinded into the dirt. Cause of death? Power creep, pay-to-win, and apathy and malice from the company that runs it. Avoid it like the plague if the plague were also on fire and making rude gestures at you.

content:
er 9, 2015
												First serious review, go easy on me.tl;dr version, everything died but the devs.review updates at bottomNow, I have been a loyal player of this game since around 2008, despite my hours on Steam. Originally, I played the game off of Nexon's actual download site so I'll take that into account. I've invested over a thousand hours into this game, and boy was it great! The community was very fun to just socialize with and everyone was nice. The party quests differentiated from each other so it wasn't too repetitive. Everybody also worked together to help each other level up, and villages were filled with friends; until about a year or two ago.. Those were the good days.I'm not necessarily saying the game itself is really bad now, but the community just went kablam. It's like napalm upon the nice people of the game. Henceforth, many players disappeared and the developers just turned the game into more of a pay-to-win aspect. "Whatever happened to the people?" I ask myself a lot. I always come back to this question as this was my all-time favorite game and community. I don't know. I miss the party invites from random people, and the occurence of running into strangers who become your best friend. Sometimes I think I'm all alone when I'm online since each instance is filled with afk people and others just walking around aimlessly, then logging off just like me, only to check if the game is restored to its former glory. There are also no players left that actually do party quests, an essential thing to leveling up efficiently. "The tears that come out of one eye are from nostalgia, the tears that come from the other eye are from how bad the game is.", quoted from another reviewer, is similar to what I feel about the present Maplestory.Now onto the pros and cons.Pros:+Great concept of characters+Good storyline that provides a foundation for each character+OMAIGOD THE MUSIC+Many, many places and locations to explore, with hidden quests+Content (apparently still) being added every few months or soThat's all the pros I can come up with from memory for now.Cons:-Pay to win-Screwed over community-Dead servers-Unbalanced charactersWell, that's pretty much it. If I had reviewed this game much earlier, rather than 2015, I would've given this game a recommendation. Is this game worth playing at this point? Not really, unless you're just wanting to explore the game itself. That then concludes my review.If you actually read to this point, thanks for doing so!Update: Apparently, its much easier to level up now. So easy that the game essentially hands you the exp, whereas in the past you actually had to work for it using teamwork. If you're looking for that nostalgia, it's not there anymore. Also, remember the ship you took took to Orbis and the people you met on that ship? Well, nobody uses it anymore. There's no more aspect of exploration since you can just use a dimensional portal or something, or a click and go item.Update Update: holy ♥♥♥♥ what the ♥♥♥♥, people still use basilmarket to communicate. thats a plus i guess

content:
er 20, 2014
												    After I have experienced SO much about Maplestory, from playing it since 9 years ago plus on various private servers, I think it is time to hit delete key and post a caveat for curious 12-year-old like you to see. This game does not hurt if you play with some friends. Honestly, being playing with friends is the only good way to play this game since they serve as a reminder that you still have a real life. Without such link to the reality, it is too easy to be sucked into the scheme of Maplestory that is deliberately, fundamentally created to exhaust both your mind and wallet    Because remember: the philosophy of any MMORPG is to encourage competition between players strictly on the level of vanity and facile values, being how beautiful you look, how much money you have, how high damage can you hit...... Especially when you are lonely in the game, this emotion is easily ellicited because the game encourages so in any aspect. But the trick is, we all understand there is no ending to beautiful cash shop items and the amount of currency you possess, why can't we/I keep from not coming back to torture ourselves in the grinding and trading that ultimately lead to no real satisfaction?    Because those game developers(e.g. Nexon) understand how pleasure works in us. What human desires is not a specific, final object, but a differential value through a growing experience. That is to say, pleasure is only gained through change; and after you arrive at a threshold, being it posed by the game or your brain, you are only left with emptiness. And this is when you want to start the loop again, again, and again. This is precisely why we only want to make MORE money, why we want to spend MORE cash items, and get MORE levels/damage without it ending at a specific number. This is why Nexon created so many new types of characters and jobs: they want to give you the pseudo-novel feeling each time you restart the experience, while in fact, nothing has changed about how your pleasure works. It's an everlasting loop.    So instead of clicking the "Play Game" button. Why not think about something more valuable in your life? Whether or not you are willing to participate in this collective subconscious hell of pleasure looping is your own choice. If you really want to play, play it with friends. I am lonely, I don't have friends. Since I understand all these, I decide to quit.

content:
27, 2015
												Disclamer: This is long, but my review of the game is towards the bottomAbout me: A friend recommended this game to me back in 2006 when it was still in its first few years. I downloaded it and was hooked immediately. Except for Runescape, this was my first MMORPG. My friend moved away but we kept in contact for awhile through this game, and I also "met" a lot of people in-game that i became as close as you can be in a fake world. I felt cool pretending to be 16 and people actually believing me.Starting out back in the day this game was hard. Hard in the sense that it takes a long time, effort, and collaboration even to reach the second job advancement at lvl 30. I still have my very first character at about lvl 26. This game hooks you in and keeps you grinding and doing quests all because of wanting to be like those who were lvl 70+ and had the cool job advancements. Over the years things started to get a little easier. With a new account and job classes like the cygnus knights coming out things were still looking good for this game. I was playing it more for time-wasting instead of sheer need/addiction (yes, looking back i was wildly addicted to this game). It was still something to play with my friends, but i still recognized i needed a life. Getting my first character to lvl 70 (an assasin) was a very big step for me, and when it took me forever just to get it to lvl 72 thats when i started to realize i needed to stop. FAST FORWARD 2-3 years and its summer and i think, huh i kind of want to waste some time. That summer i fell back in love with Maplestory, but for a different reason, it was so easy to level. I was able to get several characters to higher levels (60s-70s) rather quickly and it was fun to experiment with the wide set of classes that were new. But this is where Maplestory for me started to lose its touch. I would every few months or so log on and just think "Oh i wonder whats changed this time" and its always something. It isnt what I fell in love with anymore.Now in college i found myself playing this once in a blue moon if i had some down time and wanted to just relax. This game has a therapeutic sense to it that i just go around doing quests/grinding till 2AM. Nowadays it is so eay to level up i started a character and in about an hour it was at level 50. along with my 70 assasin, i have a 12X dual blade and my main character is a 135 Aran, one of my all time favorite classes (i havent really been interested in the new classes). So if you're still reading this, im almost done. Why do i still play this game? Nostalgia. Plain and simple. when you spend as much time as i have on something like this it is hard to give it up. I have wonderful MEMORIES of this game and i play now to waste time. ---------------------------------------------------ABOUT THE GAME: Pay to Win: A lot of people say its a 'pay to win' game but i have spent about $5 of NX just for looks purposes, i made my couple million mesos on sheer grit and luck with some equipment and scroll drops. Its possible without it, but it takes work. Art: This game is beautiful. Not much else to say really.Community: All about gone. As a "veteran" i can tell that it is all solo now, even the PQs can be solo. Also the free market is empty except for the stores, that should tell you something.Gameplay: If you like doing quests and grinding and doing storylines, its for you. If you're expecting something more, look elsewhere. As i have said before: this game was addicting to me, some may play for only a little but there are only extremes for this game. Either 10 hours or 1000. BE WARNED. Nexon: They dont really give a crap about their players so dont expect very good customer service (which is why i would steer clear of NX, you dont need it)Hacking: Theres in-game hackers and then there are people who hack accounts. Luckily after being off the grid for about 2-3 years i was able to come back on and have everything right where i left it. I guess i was lucky. Because of the time i put into it and how much of this game i have seen, from the beginning to the end, i can only recommend this with a word of caution. Dont invest yourself into the game but still have fun with it because it is a wild ride. I believe this game can only get a 1/10 or a 10/10 and i have to give it 10/10 for what it has been for me. You've been warned.I apoligize for the novel but this is what Maplestory has caused, it is a beautiful game and it is something that has been that nagging baby sister for the past ~10 years and it is something that i will always look back and laugh about and think of how much ******* time i put into that game.

content:
29, 2015
												This is a game that SHOULD be fun. It really SHOULD be. It has everything it needs:Awesome music, amazing graphics (You get used to the character sprites.) and lots of things to do, tons of classes that function very differently the farther you go along, but eases you into them at first.So why am I not suggesting this game?Nexon isn't the 'best' company when it comes down to it. They have a Cash Shop. You want a pet? Cash shop. You want nice looking armor to RENT to display over your current armor? Cash shop. Teleport wherever you want? Cash shop. EXP boost? Cash shop.Literally anything and everything is a Cash Shop. Yes it's not the only MMO to have it, but it clearly abuses it so much and was (Likely) one of the first MMOs to truly abuse the heck out of the system. Don't worry if you forget about it, you'll get reminded with drops, quests, and so on that there is a way to buy your way out of everything.The community itself? If you've played an MMO, you know what to expect. Generally this consists of people who speak nothing to you most of the time- except in a market, in which case you get spammed with lots of things you won't know what they mean.The best way to compare the free market on channel one is like watching ants swarm a meal. It's fascinating and disgusting at the same time...and by the way, you're the meal.You can use the forums to get in guilds which aren't bad, but even then most of the lingo is confusing- half because MS has a text limit shorter than a Twitter message, half because they have a filter that is so picky that I could never state my friend 'is' something because it gets filtered out, even if I wanted to say 'is great'Another dislike about the game is the AI. 90% of the enemies you encounter outside of dungeons  (At least up to lvl 120) use the same pattern of "I'm gonna run into you and damage you that way!" which, yeah there's hundreds of enemies, but it's all just nothing short of a pallete swap if they all get the same functionality.In the end, Maplestory has a lot of ingredients to be a great game, but too many spices put into the soup end up making a good soup turn rotten (But still look pretty). And that's the best way to describe it.

content:
er 20, 2016
												I've been playing MapleStory off and on since the year it came out, I think I was about 10. Oh lord so much of my childhood was spent pouring endless hours into this game. Something about it is addictive and enticing enough to make you come back about once a year for a week long binge. That being said, it's gone through a lot of phases as far as games go. It started out gaining a huge amount of popularity by having one of the best communities I've seen in an MMO, cute graphics, unique skills in each class, but it was largely grind based. Grind based MMO's are more tolerable if you have friends around you that also play the game, but Nexon started making it more pay to win and so eventually it thinned out a lot. Nexon respond by throwing class after class, new world after new world, new maps, and tons of other extraneous stuff to entice players to stay/come back but without addressing the pay to win problem so the game died almost beyond recovery. It was still grind based, with only three basic forms of quests - killing monsters/gathering items, jumping on platforms with obstacles, or traveling across an ever expanding map that would just suck up idle time. Since then, it seems Nexon finally started tackling some of the main problems players have been complaining about. There are faster ways to get across the map, cross-world features to elliminate the thinned out player base, it's not necessarily as grind based, there are more unique monsters popping up, and far more quests and features. It doesn't seem as pay to win, and Nexon is improving on what they have rather than just throwing more stuff at players. It's more fun than I remember it, and I never thought I'd ever describe MapleStory as fun again. The community is still thin but there is more to do in the game and it's more balanced than ever. Overall it's worth a shot, but if you want your character to look remotely decent you're still going to have to spend money.

ber 15, 2015
 Nostalgia and the big numbers blind me If you've never heard of Maplestory just skip it. To be completely honest with you the only reason I got this game on Steam was for the nostalgia. I've been playing this game on and off for so many years. (Since 2006) This game was fantastic, but it was ruined by it's absurdly high damage numbers, (which get so damn high that Nexon has to raise the cap on damage) The insane high prices of the free market, and the sheer amount of classes. (There's 32 classes! THIRTY TWO! I was so happy when Pirate first came out.) Oh and the community. Do you like 12 year olds? Well that's basically a majority of the community. Here's my recent adventures. Recently I played this game AGAIN for the 90th time. I chose Adventurer my bread and butter, I picked Magician and picked the Cleric tree.  As soon as you hit level 20 you get bombarded by all these alerts. "JOIN THE NEW CHAT SYSTEM." "EVENT!!!!!" "GACHAPON GACHAPON!" I got very annoyed very quickly. After a very quick leveling grind to level 100, I got my fourth job Bishop. I was very happy that I made it to level 100 because back in my day I've gotten a level 100 Dark Knight.  Soon after my 4th job I realised. ♥♥♥♥ there's 150 more levels. I gave up after that. The community annoyed me the grind was boring (Just spammed HS for bonus Xp) and I didn't want to spend any real life money to cube any items or scroll anything.  Final Verdict:  It WAS a good game. The game is no longer enjoyable. But my inner 12 year old makes me want to love it.  Nostalgia is the only reason I would see someone play this. The game on it's own is a grind all the way to level 250. The big numbers are blinding and are hard to track, the classes have no "uniqueness" It's all about DAMAGE DAMAGE DAMAGE.  5/10 Nice nostalgia trip, game isn't fun anymore Edit:Went from being most recommended negative review to not existing at all.If you can't take backlash for your dying game consider fixing it instead of hiding negative reviews. Thank you for hiding my review though!Proof: http://imgur.com/nVIs5tXMy review doesn't even show up. If you can't take negative reviews please just delete all of them. If you say that this is an outdated review, please look at most recommended reviews. There's reviews older or just about the same age as mine. Please delete their reviews too then.

content:
er 25, 2013
												I really do wish I could recommend this game. I have spend many, many, hours on it. I was drawn in by the excellent storyline and seemingly endless levels.But then it hits you. The level curve is absurd. The content is either sparse or not worth your time (good luck leveling between 120 - 150) and the top play is just far too repetative. There is always a best build, and they are painfully obvious. All these status effects, elemental damage, forget them. Only element that matters is holy, and most enemies die before you can do whatever horrible status effect to them.Maplestory, gameplay wise, seems to be hanging you between faster leveling crowd attacks or better boss-killing single target attacks. Usually you end up a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mix of all of them, and it seems like that's the track most classes are now moving.Really, the only difference between most of these classes is their DPS and weapon of choice. While this one has to balance light/dark, this one rides on a panther, and this one is so adorably ridiculously pink, it doesn't make a bit of difference. You're either a bishop or a killer. Class synergy? Nope. Tanks and Strikers? Nope. I guess the best example of this are the boss battles, which just involve going down your attacks, drinking crap tons of potions, and watching a screen literally covered with colorful multi digit numbers. You do this for an hour, and if you can't do it under a hour, you lose. Fun.There is so much to like about Maplestory, but even more to hate. Honestly, I play it for the community. I'm not saying the game is awful, I'm just saying it is intensely flawed.

content:
y 8
												I started playing this game when pirates came out. I used to love this game I really did. What I loved the most out of this game was the sense of being part of a community. The community is still active with an estimated 50,000-70,000 players but will continue to dwindle since less people join the game than there are leaving. I left because I didn't like the direction the game was taking.I can't say if the game is still worth playing.. All but one server, the Reboot server, are pay to win. If you have the time to do mindless grinding then the Reboot server is for you (keep in mind that you cannot trade anything in this server). Find yourself a guild and hopefully you find some nice people to chat with. I don't recommend joining the non-reboot servers anymore as the majority of the old veterans are one of the most etilist and toxic players out there, and that's coming from the veteran player I am. Pretty much the normal servers are kept alive by the whales who spend tons of money in the game still. Anyone willing to pay can to be on top but I decided to not spend the money myself, it seems pointless and unfun instead of working towards progressing your character yourself. One of the things I really disliked about this game was the introduction of the potential system. Potential widened the gap between rich and poor players. It divided the community even further. There are a ton of potential related items in the cash shop that give an unfair advantage to players with lots of money to drop in non-Reboot servers. Reboot is just a band-aid for the problem potentials created in this game. Reboot is a server Nexon created that solved many pay to win aspects, however this comes with many drawbacks, including the inability to trade with one another within the server. Another problem I saw was that Nexon was nerfing party related quests and raids, it was encouraging people to go solo instead of partying with other people which is what I loved from this game (as of today you'll rarely see anyone doing party quests, most people are grinding now instead of doing PQs/Boss Runs/Raids to level up). Now that the damage cap has been removed there is little reason to party with others to do stuff if you're decently funded. One other minor problem I saw is that Nexon created tons of servers, there was no reason to create more, the population wasn't even increasing and it further divided the playerbase. They finally merged many of the barren servers into single servers but are still even less populated than the top 3 populated non Reboot servers.The game gets minor updates monthly with the occasional major update every now and then, so the game is still alive in that aspect. Thanks to Nexon Korea's ongoing support for the game, there's many more things to do than you could do in old MapleStory which is one of the few things this MMO has going. If you are looking for a good MMO to play I recommend you look elsewhere, but if you really want to try it out, go join the Reboot server, it is the most populated server and hopefully you find some nice people to chat with.TL:DR The game is extremely pay to win if you're not playing the Reboot server (keep in mind that you cannot trade in this server). I recommend joining the reboot server only if youre willing to try the game out. The game has an average of 50000-70000 players at the moment.

content:
2, 2016
												To give some context, I've been playing on/off since Beta. So I have a nostalgia for this game I cannot shake. Therefore, at the time of writing this review, I have 912 hours of this game on my Steam account. But don't get me wrong. Most of this was just me AFKing overnight to sell things, because if you want to have a shop that you can leave open without playing the game, you have to pay a crazy amount of money. I think it's like, I dunno, $3 for a 24 hour shop. Yeah. Meanwhile, it's only $1.80 for a 3 month permit to do the same thing, but you have to be online. Seems fair, right? Yeah. Anyways, here's the review lmao+ Surprisingly fun combat+ Consistently updated+ Several different classes+ Levelling is straightforward and easy+ Reboot server takes the pay to win out of the game (but also removes other features as a result, encouraging people to keep playing on the P2W servers as well)+ Very cute style, have had a lot of fun customizing my character with gear.~ Simple Crafting system (Both good and bad, because those who don't like crafting in MMOs typically won't have trouble using it, but it also makes it boring for those who love in-depth crafting systems in MMOs.)- Pay to win out the ♥♥♥. People sell their godly weapons and armor on Paypal. Anyone with a few hundred dollars can become number one in a day.- Outdated, constantly lags and crashes, built on old framework and needs updating. The sequel, Maplestory 2, looks fun but will probably never come out globally.- Once you reach a certain level, your daily routine typically involves fighting the standard bosses for about an hour or two then keeping your shop open overnight to sell more and buy more gear/cosmetics. It's a massive grind til the very end.- Pay 2 Fashion. You have a very small, if even any, selection of hairs/faces at the beginning. The only way to change them is with NX. No joke, you have to pay real money to change your hair and face. Of course, you can just pay people to gift you a coupon with in-game money, but if you want to have enough in-game cash to pay someone to do that, you either have to beg or pay real money to get gear to grind for these things. In short, unless you're insanely patient or have wealthy friends, you're going to be coerced into buying NX with real cash. Because looking ugly in an MMO sucks. Oh, and not to mention, the best hairs are in Royal Coupons and the likes, which have a RANDOM SELECTION of 6-8 hairs, of which at least half usually look terrible. This game wants your money. That's why it's still alive. And it works.Overall: Giant cash grab. Still fun if you have the money. If you don't like looking decent and don't care about bossing, then sure, I can see how you can enjoy this game, but honestly, who's going to go to this outdated MMO and do that? There are better MMOs out there. Don't waste your time here.

y 2, 2014
												First of all I don't have 9 hours on this game. I have a few thousand on this game. I just played the client version most of the time. Honestly, when this game came out way back when in '05, I played the ♥♥♥♥ out of it. It was hella fun but it was also really hard. I mean if you were level 50 you had great respect. Now getting to level 50 can be done in 2 hours as apposed to 2 months of training 4 hours a day. I mean like if you got to lv200 back then people would waste money to acknowledge you for what you have done. Now if you get to level 200 its just a race to 250 or to get super high damage and solo bosses to make real money on paypal or some ♥♥♥♥. Then later on they made Big Bang which made it super easy. Big Bang continues on and now its hard again. They raise the level cap from 200-250. Still takes like 3-5 days to get to Lv250 is unknown how long it will take because no one has reached there yet. In my opinion, this game has become completely pay to win. Nexon has declined in their service from where they started. Before buying NX was for like for clothes that didn't do jack ♥♥♥♥. But then nexon was all like, "Lets make every piece of equipment ♥♥♥♥, and put a bunch of NX items to scroll them, reset their potenial, protect them from being destroyed and a bunch of other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t." That really made me mad and now I ended up spending more then $7000 on this game. I ended up making Close to $10,000 in paypal credit over time but that was only because I played way too much. I farmed bosses and scrolled and sold items all day and all night. I got sucked in and do me a favor, never get sucked in. I was lucky to make that much money back. content:
r 22, 2016
												Alright so this game is a mix with meBack then, I was a beta tester in 2002, a year before the game released. The game used to be randomized at the character selection including you as the player having to roll the dice for your stats as your beginning class. Now it just feels like the characters have no variety, with Phantoms, Xenon, Kinesis and other classes.It used to be just the explorers, warrior, archer etc and back then the commmunity was amazing.Now gamers in general are pretty anti-social, I could even say that communitys in games like Minecraft or any other indie games have better communities now.If only Nexon saw the worth in the nostalgia of the old maple. I know they made the reboot server, but that isn't really much to provide everything about the old Maple.MapleSTORY, this game at this point has no story. The story that we all took back then ended, the player was supposed to go through their own personal story and the game's story at the same time, but now it's just... nothing, no friends, nothing. Hackers are invading a lot and ruining the game's experience, and the big players aren't even around anymore. Areas like Henesys, kerning city just feels DEAD. Afk players are there but not really playing anything. I remember being a kid and talking about Anime and such around Henesys and having fun little arguments, and those were the times when people didn't take everything so seriously. Maplestory used to be pretty innocent, but now kids are cursing in the game and such and it ruins the experience. Nexon ruined the games by removing Gapachon and adding cubes and other buy to play stuff and it turned a game where socializing and playing with your best pals into a buy to play anti social place. Gameplay is the same but the characters feel WAY TOO OP, and leveling is way too fast. The HUD is different too, I prefer the new one though so thats fine. Character creation is somewhat better, more variety in hairstyles and some of them, you had to pay back then. Seasonal Events still are pretty dead and overall, this game is dead. I think old maplers such as myself placed down the maple leaf for the new generation already. BUT, if you have a group of friends and you guys want a game to play, PLAY MAPLESTORY! It's pretty fun with friends, even though you grind extremely fast and level up fast. I rate this game 7/10 but back then it would've been a 10/10 for me.

number of helpful: 36 of 45 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 29, 2016
												Here is the thing, It isn't exactly the game itself, as much as it is the community. When the game first came out, the community for it was amazing! Everywhere you looked, you could see a player in every map. It was a game where you had to work together to make any progress. You knew the big name players; FangBlade, Tigger, CurryIsHot, etc. The community was there. It was loving, it was caring, it was a game that you wanted to play with friends instead of alone. It wasn't so much how long it took to get somewhere, as opposed to how you got there. Now the game is just too quick and easy to do anything. There are far too many classes, and instead of using skills from each class; (for example, one of the most famous party quests, the Ludibrium Tower PQ, you NEEDED to have at least a magician and a thief in your party otherwise you could not complete the party quest) is now replaced with 'HEY I CAN BEAT EVERY BOSS IN THE GAME IN 2 DAYS BY MYSELF BECAUSE I BOUGHT NX'. It just doesn't have the same player base, and I believe that is the reason so many people are quitting.As someone who has played since 2006, these 10 years have really brought a change to my eyes on the game I once loved.Here are some key points:1) The game is too rushed now. I know leveling slow sounds boring, but back in the day the excitement of getting to level 21 after hours of work so you can start Kerning PQing with your friends. Getting your 2nd job took work and then going to Ludi PQ was another fun adventure when you had friends to do it with. Getting tracks and looking for the best 'clicker' to get you into the PQs and what not. It was fun. Someone being level 70 back then was amazing. You'd look up to them. Now you can get it within 5 hours of playing hard. When Zakum first came out, for a long time there was a select few who could even dream about getting a zakum helmet, now everyone has one.2) Pay to win. They added all this new stuff to upgrade your items like cubes and I don't even know what else. Back in the day the only thing that NX bought you was cool hair, clothes and pets. Now, if you wana be the best at this game, you have to pay a lot of money for it with cubes, and other NX items.3) Simplicity. This is what is turning me off at the moment. Back when I played, there was only Mage, Bowmen, Theifs and Warriors (and the rare 'beginner' main), and it was awsome. Each class had strengths and weaknesses at different points in the game, and the world wasn't too gaint to explore. The old saying 'if it ain't broke don't fix it' I think. People enjoyed making one of each of the 4 classes (even more if you wanted Spearman, fighter, F/P mage, clerics, bandits etc). Now, when I opened maplestory, I see like 20 different classes at least, and each probably have their own sub-classes, it's just too much imo. Back then it was easy to balance (in fact they almost never had to balance any classes cause they were so equal) but, I imagine with this many classes now, sometimes they get out of balance and certain ones outshine heavily.

content:
ry 3, 2014
 This game... Thousands of hours into this game, and I  highly  do  not  recommend it. Only very few hours were recorded because I always played through the launcher and not Steam. Anyways;...Either one of two things will happen:1) You won't like this game, and quit playing after like 10 hours tops. 2) You'll really enjoy this game for the first 5,000 hours, then realize you wasted a couple years playing one of the worst MMO's out there. I enjoyed this game when I was a kid, quit playing it for a year, came back to it, quit playing, and so on. This game is one of those "Pay-to-win" games, where everything is based off how much money you feel like dumping into this game. And that right there, is what makes it so successful. It's a nice game, yeah, but not worth the time and money you'll put into it. After a couple hundred bucks put into cosmetics, "damage", any stupid ♥♥♥♥ there is, you then ask yourself what you're doing. "Well, it's not a waste if you enjoy playing the game!" I suppose so. That's what I said at first, but hey. It's your money, your feel to the game. I would recommend this game if it wasn't such an addictive pay-to-win game. The Pro's:+Enjoyable classes to play as+Countless different styles of gameplay+Endless outfits, equips, weapons, etc.+Kind(ish) community (Average MMO)+It's a good time-waster+Free world, do whatever you want+Cute graphics, nice way to express yourselfThe Con's:+Hundreds if not thousands of hours will be put into it+Pay-to-win game+Starts to get boring after a couple months+Too many restrictions (Treated as 10 year olds)+Terrible storylines, only thing that matters is levels+Grinding levels takes hours upon hours spamming the same buttons+Lots of hackers, scammers, spammers, botters, etc.+Above all,  waste of time. I recommend not even trying it out, and just leaving it there. You'll end up  hating  it one way or another. My opinion, is that yes, it was a great game growing up, but wasted many hours of my childhood while growing up. And money.  And money. Gameplay: 5/10Free world: 7/10Style: 5.5/10Graphics: 6/10Addictiveness: 11/10 Overall: 6/10

content:
2016
												I first played maplestory maybe 7 or 8 years ago and at first it was fun. (Note: my main interest is quests.)I remembered it was a game that, if you are a casual player, got harder and harder to progress as you went on. Eventually I stopped playing because it would take far too long to level up and make any sort of meaningful progress. Plus items like scrolls to increase certain traits of a weapon were pricey and overall the game was just slow.Fast forward to 2016 and I am back! It's a lot of fun now. Nexon have made certain parts of the game painless and have introduced new niche areas. Not interested in monsters or mapleworld? How about becoming a star/celebrity over at Star Planet? Want something different to the world of monsters and magic? Check out Friends Story, one of the alternative dimensions that's set in the modern world where you play a student!If you just want to do quests and wander about - the game now has a very good guide that will recommend the quests that are right for your level. I followed this guide and levelled up quickly, giving me more options to explore other parts of the game and even take on a big boss or two.Improving your weapons and equipment is now simple to do and doesn't take long at all.My main criticism of the game is that it seems like a neverending mess. Little to no structure and if you were looking for a main storyline to follow there isn't really one. Instead there are lots of short story arcs, or series of quests (one leading on to the next), which is great while it lasts but leaves you thinking - now what?Playing alone is fine, and I mainly solo, however playing with friends is a lot more fun.

Expect to see smartphones and dumb cliche stories about high school life and pre-teen focused content. MapleStory was a fantasy world full of dragons and magical items with a feel of that little Warrior, Thief, Mage, Archer. It's just thrown out that feeling that makes you feel like a true adventurer and puts you in these cliche IM THE MAIN CHARACTER AND I MUST DO THIS IN ORDER TO BE STRONGER stories. The old days were full of nice people, people willing to talk with you and go on quests with you. "Hey dude are you doing this quest to get this item" "Yeah wanna party up?" was a very common thing to hear. Nowadays it's folk rushing to level 30 and farming spots saying "cc pls". It's disgusting. You don't have to agree with me it's just how I feel as to what this once magnificient game has become. By the way, almost everyone looks the same due to the popular looks taking over most of the population. RED put into critical condition, Friendstory finished it off and cut life support.

content:
3, 2015
												I'm not as much of a reviewer that is going to dislike the game just because I have nostalgia goggles on, I'm going to give you a view of the game while including my own experiences to show you how the game is.This game as it is, in 2015, is an extremely pay-to-win driven game. Over the past 6 years (for me) they've consistently been dumbing down the game to where it practically plays itself with things like 100 level tomes which just make your character level 100 no questions asked, no effort produced. The sidequests are generally repetitive and unrewarding (and unrewarding isn't necessarily a bad thing if the quest was fun). They have special global quests (which when were created happened once a month or couple of months) every single day which reward you with gear for your level and experience automatically, you do not have to go out and kill mobs/bosses to get rare drops or complete a questline anymore.When I began playing Maplestory in 2009 it was a simple game that allowed you to do practically whatever you wanted, you had no guidance (or very little) and were encouraged to explore the entire world which made the game very fun, it was absolutely great at making you feel accomplished and as if you discovered something new. Now you have something called a Hyper Teleport Rock at almost all times (from the global quests mentioned prior) that can take you literally anywhere in the game, no long trekking, boss battles, or sense of adventure. You can avoid all of that. The game was more challenging which made it more enjoyable when you leveled up. Back then (pre Big Bang), to put how easy they've made the game into perspective, to get to level 30 generally took around a month and level 70 took maybe 4-6 months. Now, with no exaggeration, you can get to level 30 in an hour and level 70 in about 4 hours. You can hit level 200 (which pre Big Bang would have taken a year or more) in a week, maybe less.This game also never had a story, just quests. There was no "ultimate evil" or dedicated storyline, but they made that with the Cygnus Knights. I joined the game again just to play the Black Heaven storyline which was extremely boring. The character dialogue just droned on and on with no meaningful interactions, it was almost entirely just characters making cheesy jokes to eachother and other useless non sequiturs which completely dilutes the idea of an overbearing being, so I found myself just holding down my spacebar to fly through the dialogue a lot and I never felt like I missed any information. Then there were things you had to do, and you could tell it was just all filler content. You had to kill 30 of these robots, then go through the portal and kill 40 of them, then go through the portal and kill 60 of them and I wish I was kidding, you ACTUALLY do that up to 100 robots. And you do that a couple more times. You also do the same thing with collecting things from monsters you kill. They're forcing a story that has no weight and is so clearly thrown together that it hurts.This game is great if you're looking for just a straight casual MMORPG to just ♥♥♥♥ around in and waste time, if you want an experience and a challenge I would go find another game.

content:
8, 2014
												With the direction this game is currently going in - No, I would not recommend playing MapleStory. I have been playing MapleStory for years, as such I've chosen to stick by it through good times and bad; but I have to say that I am not happy with Global MapleStory's choices, as of late. It seems that Global MapleStory wants to make itself the superior version of MapleStory, but it has a very half-♥♥♥♥♥ way of trying to achieve this. So far, pretty much every attempt at being different from the mother version of the game, KMS(Korean MapleStory), has been an annoying step-down from what could have been awesome. For the last few years, GMS has made unneccesary changes to content coming from KMS to make it seem like their version of MapleStory is somehow "different". The problem is, these changes have always been sloppy, and they've continued to hold the game back from being much better. In my opinion, what GMS should be focusing on is creating completely NEW content that could easily go side-by-side with anything we receive from KMS, rather than making nitpicky changes and removing pieces of content that players have been looking forward to for months. The main problem with the game is how Pay-To-Win it feels, and it is sad to see that unlike KMS, which has been slowely making attempts to make the game fair for non-paying players, GMS has continued to hold the game back in its Pay-To-Win state. For example, in the Korean MapleStory as part of the "RED" update they added things like an Auction House, allowing players to buy and sell items from other users without needing to purchase a permit with real-money. GMS has opted not to add this to the game, claiming that it had some "problems that needed fixing" but months have passed and we've seen no news on it actually coming for us. Another example of ways that KMS had attempted to walk away from Pay-To-Win (and another example of how GMS simply ignored those changes to continue on their Pay-To-Win path) is the "Maple Mileage" system which allowed you to optain mileage through playing the game, and having the option to pay for Cash Shop (real money) items using Mileage instead! This meant that anybody who played long enough could have the option to EARN Cash Shop items through playing if they chose to do so. Of course, in a decision that surprised no-one, GMS simply did not make any attempts to add this feature to our version of the game. There are many other features that helped even the playing field with paying players and non-paying players, and I could go on-and-on about what else GMS has decided to skip, but I'll stop there. (If you'd like, you could look up things like Additional Options which added all sorts of randomized stats to your items to help players who weren't quite powerful enough to fight Bosses for their loot. You could also look into how KMS added the ability to buy 'Maple Points' with in-game currency. Maple Points being an alternative to NX, which is what you use to buy things from the real-money 'Cash Shop'.)I continue playing this game in hopes that one day these things and more will be added to make the game friendlier to non-paying players, but only time will tell if any of these will happen. For now I would stay away from MapleStory, as it continues to give the Free-To-Play genre a bad name.

content:
r 6, 2014
												In 2006 AD summoning bag has been planted.<typing noises>    XxSinThief91xX: wht hppn lah     lolthegame: Someone set us up the Pink Bean!     RapidFire: we get the whisper!     XxSinThief91xX: wht     RapidFire: (turns on whisper cheat)     XxSinThief91xX: its u     Nexon: How are you maplers?     Nexon: All your jewgolds are belong to us. You are on your way to buying NX.     XxSinThief91xX: wht u say!?     Nexon: You have no chance to refuse make your time. Ha ha ha ha!     xHermit1337: mesos plz     Nexon: Your NX transaction is complete. Thank you. I grew up playing this game as soon as it was out in North America, all the way back in 2005. I was just a kid then, not even a middle schooler. I spent most of my free time on the computer playing the game with my brother and his friends. Back then, leveling was SLOW; it would take a week just to get to Lv.30. The only way to level at all in your 2nd job was to PQ the same quests over and over half a dozen times just to level up once, and even once you did, you didn't find much content at the next level. Because of this, most of the original game was extremely social. The goal to getting anywhere was cooperating with other players, as interaction was key to success. Because of the snail-leveling, you would spend most of your time in one of the 6 towns, listening to gossip and learning important information, getting into Parties and Guilds, and making friends. This game was key to my survival, as I live in a hellish redneck ghetto town. My online friends helped me see the light through dark times, and I owe them everything; even a decade later. I stopped being very active after 2008, but did check on the game after BB. My original draft of this review was negative, but the modern maple is loaded with new content and 5x as many classes as the original game. Leveling is fast now; I could get 10 characters to level 30 in a day. Even then, there's still a lot of grinding. The EXP you need is a fraction of what it used to be originally. Money is still an issue, and the economy makes no sense to me. The cash shop is still a waste of money, and you are forced to spend real $ on skillbooks, or else your characters will be stunted in their later growth. The modern community is very antisocial because of the soloing aspects. It's not the same game I remember as a child, but this could still provide you hundreds of hours of content, and it's been free for a decade! If you're bored and want a free mmo to try, this would be one of your destinations for many years, and for good reason.

number of helpful: 17 of 23 people (74%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
8, 2016
												TL;DR:PROS: levelling with quests and not just grinds, a lot of classes, findable good equips, great for new players (and old ones if they can get over the fact that the game isn't the same as it was 16 years ago)CONS: quiet community in-game, some party quests are completely deadI see a lot of reviews talking about how much the game has changed and how there's no nostalgia left for us older players. As an older player myself (I've been playing Maple off and on since 2006), I disagree. What brought me back to Maple after the last four year haitus I had was the nostalgia, but what kept me playing was the complete rehaul of the game.When I was a kid with dial-up internet, getting to the first job advancement was difficult. Fast forward to today: I have played almost every class through into the fourth advancement. Yes, it's been made a lot easier, but it's also reasonable now; any player can get a good diversity  of content regardless of experience or skill. The endless 10-20 level grind on the same map is gone, now theme dungeons and quests offer the best leveling chance, which is loads more fun. In fact, quests used to be altogether useless, so this change is super awesome.There's so many classes now! I was super happy when I came back to all the new classes. I actually can't wait for more to come out so I have more skills to try out. (I'm hoping there's an all-new class soon with new clothing equips and not just weapons.)The addition of spell traces and the equip enhancement system actually reduces the pay-to-win aspect that has ALWAYS (as in FOREVER, as in THIS IS NOTHING NEW) been a part of Maple. It offers people the chance to have good equips but without the ridiculous cost and rarity of scrolls. Equipment drops have been completely rehauled and now have hidden potentials, allowing players to find their equips without having to spend mesos or real money and to make a decent bit of mesos that help in the later game with pots and the like. (Side note: I remember the days of the scrolled out sauna robe, can't nobody tell me the new equip drop system is bad.)Us older players are not the major target of this game anymore and that's OKAY. It's for those kids coming in at the same age when we started back in the day. It's not entirely Maple and Nexon's fault that the previous audience left, a good deal of people left because they got older and found other games, particularly MOBAs. (Admittedly, the game community has gotten quieter and some party quests are dead, but, again, see previous point.)All-in-all, it's not right to make a crappy review on the game because it's changed over the course of over a decade and a half. The game is different, even easier, and that's totally cool. I think it's a great choice for new, young gamers with its cute graphics and background music. And if older players approach it as a different game than the one they remember, it can be really great for them too.
